t: Isaiah 42
The Servant’s Mission
“This*pn is my servant; I strengthen him, this*ln is my chosen one; I delight in him. I*ln have put my Spirit on him; he*ln will bring justice to the nations.
He*ln will not cry out or shout or*ln make his voice heard in the streets.
He*ln will not break a bruised reed, and*ln he will not put out a smoldering wick; he*ln will faithfully bring justice.
He*ln will not grow weak or be discouraged until*ln he has established justice on earth. The*ln coasts and islands will wait for his instruction.”

This*pn is what God, the Lord,*s says — who*ln created the heavens and stretched them out, who*ln spread out the earth and what comes from it, who*ln gives breath to the people on it and*ln spirit to those who walk on it—

“I*ln am the Lord.*s I have called you for*ln a righteous purpose, and*ln I will hold you by your hand. I*ln will watch over you, and I will appoint you to*ln be a covenant for the people and*ln a light to the nations,
in*ln order to open blind eyes, to*ln bring out prisoners from the dungeon, and*ln those sitting in darkness from the prison house.
I*ln am the Lord.*s That is my name, and*ln I will not give my glory to another or*ln my praise to idols.
The*ln past events have indeed happened. Now*ln I declare new events; I*ln announce them to you before they occur.”
A Song of Praise
Sing*pn a new song to the Lord;*s sing*ln his praise from the ends of the earth, you*ln who go down to the sea with all that fills it, you*ln coasts and islands with your inhabitants.
Let*ln the desert and its cities shout, the*ln settlements where Kedar dwells cry aloud. Let*ln the inhabitants of Sela sing for joy; let*ln them cry out from the mountaintops.
Let*ln them give glory to the Lord*s and*ln declare his praise in the coasts and islands.
The*ln Lord*s advances like a warrior; he*ln stirs up his zeal like a soldier. He*ln shouts, he roars aloud, he*ln prevails over his enemies.
“I*pn have kept silent from ages past; I*ln have been quiet and restrained myself. But*ln now, I will groan like a woman in labor, gasping*ln breathlessly.
I*ln will lay waste mountains and hills and*ln dry up all their vegetation. I*ln will turn rivers into islands and*ln dry up marshes.

I*ln will lead the blind by a way they did not know; I*ln will guide them on paths they have not known. I*ln will turn darkness to light in front of them and*ln rough places into level ground. This*ln is what I will do for them, and*ln I will not abandon them.
They*ln will be turned back and utterly ashamed — those*ln who trust in an idol and*ln say to a cast image, ‘You*ln are our gods! ’
Israel’s Blindness and Deafness
“Listen,*pn you deaf! Look,*ln you blind, so that you may see.
Who*ln is blind but my servant, or*ln deaf like my messenger I am sending? Who*ln is blind like my dedicated one, or*ln blind like the servant of the Lord?*s
Though*ln seeing many things, you pay no attention. Though*ln his ears are open, he does not listen.”
Because*pn of his righteousness, the Lord*s was pleased to*ln magnify his instruction and make it glorious.

But*ln this is a people plundered and looted, all*ln of them trapped in holes or*ln imprisoned in dungeons. They*ln have become plunder with*ln no one to rescue them and*ln loot, with no one saying, “Give it back!”
Who*ln among you will hear this? Let*ln him listen and obey in the future.

Who*ln gave Jacob to the robber, and*ln Israel to the plunderers? Was*ln it not the Lord?*s Have*ln we not sinned against him? They*ln were not willing to walk in his ways, and*ln they would not listen to his instruction.
So*ln he poured out his furious anger and*ln the power of war on Jacob. It*ln surrounded him with fire, but he did not know it; it*ln burned him, but he didn’t take it to heart.
